questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the format of the death certificate recommended by the WHO?

choices.text: Other significant conditions contributing to death
Age of person at the time of death

questions.solution:
Age at the time of death is not included in the WHO format for a death certificate.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: You are filling the death certificate of a patient who died from rupture of the myocardium following an acute myocardial infarction. This was because of thrombosis in the coronary artery due to longstanding atherosclerosis. What will you record in line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Coronary artery thrombosis is to be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place.

The flow of events in this patient is as follows:

As per the recommendations of Forty-Third World Health Assembly 1990, an additional line (d) was added below (c) in part I of the death certificate, as approved by the WHO.

Part II will only be filled up with a significant condition contributing to the death but not related to the disease or condition causing it.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient was suffering from multi-drug resistant tuberculosis. He died of respiratory failure due to lobar pneumonia. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Lobar pneumonia is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate. Line I (a) consists of the immediate cause of death such as the disease/condition. Immediate cause is the immediate/terminal event leading to death

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Lobar pneumonia
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: MDR tuberculosis.
  • II- HIV

Respiratory failure is a mode of dying in this patient. It is not the cause of death.

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs of death.

Simply put, respiratory failure is 'how he died' whereas lobar pneumonia is 'why he died'. Therefore, lobar pneumonia (why he died) is the cause of the death.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a morbidity indicator?
questions.solution:
Years of potential life lost is not a morbidity indicator. It is a mortality indicator. It is the years of potential life lost through premature death.

Notification rates, spells of sickness and incidence are examples of morbidity indicators.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about rate is false?

choices.text: It measures the occurrence of an event in a population.
It has no specification of time.
It's numerator is mostly part of the denominator.

questions.solution:
Rate is the measurement of the occurrence of a particular event in a given time. Hence, rates have a specification in time.

Examples include crude death rate, incidence rate etc.

Related Pearl: Rate, Ratio and Proportion

  • Rate:
    • It measures the occurrence of a particular event in a population in a given time.
    • It consists of a numerator, denominator, time specification and multiplier.
    • Numerator is often part of the denominator.
    • Examples: Crude death rate, incidence rate.
  • Ratio:
    • It expresses a relation in size between two random quantities.
    • It consists of only numerator and denominator and no time specification.
    • The numerator is not part of the denominator.
    • Examples: sex ratio, doctor-population ratio.
  • Proportion:
    • It is a ratio that indicates the relation in magnitude of a part of a whole.
    • The numerator is always part of the denominator.
    • Proportions are usually expressed as percentage and it is often measured at a point in time.

questions.text: To calculate the crude death rate of a country, at what time of the year is the population assessed?
questions.solution:
The crude death rate is a mortality indicator, which uses the mid-year population as its denominator. The mid-year population is always attributed as the population on 1st July of any year.

Hence for calculating the crude death rate, the population is assessed on the 1st of July.

 

Related Pearl: Crude death rate

Crude death rate:

  • The crude death rate is the simplest measure of mortality.
  • It is the number of deaths (from all causes) per 1000 estimated mid-year population in one year, in a given place.
  • Crude death rate =  (Number of deaths per year)/(Mid-year population) x 1000
  • Disadvantage: lacks comparability for communities with populations that differ in age, sex, race, etc.
  • Currently, the crude death rate in India is 6.0.

questions.text: For which of the following purposes is age-specific death rates not used?

choices.text: Identifying specific age groups at risk
Comparison for different causes within the same population
Comparison between different sexes in relation to accidents
Comparison between different age groups in relation to accidents

questions.solution:
Sex-specific death rates are used for the comparison between sexes and not age-specific death rates.

Age-specific death rates are used for:

  • Comparison for different causes within the same population.
  • Comparison between different age groups in relation to a particular event.
  • Identifying specific age groups at risk.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note:

Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 500 of them contracted a disease X, out of which 75 died. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is given by the formula:

The total number of cases of disease X= 500

The total number of deaths= 75

Hence the case fatality rate= 75/500 x 100 = 15%

questions.text: Which of the following is the simplest measure of the burden of a disease in a community?
questions.solution:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure to estimate the burden of a disease in a community.

It is commonly used for broad disease groups and when population data is not available.It is of limited value in making comparisons between populations and in identifying risk groups.

questions.text: Standardisation was done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries. What is the rationale behind this?

choices.text: Due to difference in number of deaths.
Due to difference in age distribution.
Due to difference in the population density.
Due to difference in cause of death.

questions.solution:
While comparing the mortality rates of two countries, the standardization of rates is done due to differences in age distribution.

The two types of standardisation include direct and indirect.

In both methods, a standard population is chosen where the numbers in each age and sex group are known and its choice is arbitrary.

The commonly used standard populations are the Segi world population and the European standard population.

Related Pearl: Standardization of Rates in Epidemiology

Standardization of rates is done to allow for comparison of health statuses of two populations after adjustments for age, sex, etc. using a standard population.

A) Direct Standardization:

  • Direct method uses actual age-specific death rates on standard population.
  • Concept is summarized by the given diagram:
  • It is feasible only if actual specific rates in subgroups of the observed population are available, along with number of people in each subgroup.

B) Indirect Standardization

  • Indirect method uses standard age-specific death rates on actual population.
  • Concept is summarized by the given diagram:
  • One form of this is called the Standardized Mortality Ratio.
    • It is a ratio of the total number of deaths that occur in the study group to the number of deaths that would have been expected to occur if that study group had experienced the death rates of a standard population.
    • It is given as x 100.
    • If the value is >100, then greater mortality risk and if the value is <100, lesser risk.
    • It does not need known specific rates for adjustment, unlike the direct method.
    • It can be used if the event of interest is the occurrence of disease rather than death.
  • Other indirect methods are life table analysis, regression techniques and multivariate analysis.

questions.text: A party was attended by 110 people out of which, 40 did not eat fruit salad. Among the rest of those who ate fruit salad, 55 developed food poisoning. What is the attack rate?
questions.solution:
The attack rate is calculated by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of new cases is 55 and the total number of those at risk is 70 as they ate the fruit salad.

Therefore attack rate = 55/70 X 100 = 78.6%.

 Attack rate is an incidence rate. It is used only when the population is exposed to risk for a limited period.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: Out of a family of 4 members, one of them developed COVID-19 infection. Four days later, 2 other members developed the same. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
Secondary attack rate is calculated by the following:

In this scenario, there is one primary case. The total exposed contacts are the other 3 members of the family. The number of persons developing the disease is 2. 

So, secondary attack rate = 2/3 x 100 = 66%.

Note: The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: Which of the following study designs would you prefer for calculating the incidence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The study designs which can be used to calculate incidence are cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about incidence are true?
  1. It is more than prevalence.
  2. It measures new and old cases.
  3. It is not affected by the duration of disease.
  4. It is a type of proportion.
  5. It gives insight into the effectiveness of health services.
questions.solution:
Incidence is not affected by the duration of the disease. Analysis of incidence rates may provide useful insights into the effectiveness of the health services provided.

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.

Prevalence is more than incidence as it is the product of incidence and duration.

Incidence is a type of rate and not a proportion.

questions.text: A medical officer noticed that there were 300 new cases of cholera in an area in a year. The total population in that area is 30,000. What is the incidence of cholera?
questions.solution:
The incidence of cholera is 10 per 1000.

Incidence is given by the formula:

In this scenario number of new cases = 300

Total population = 30,000

Hence the incidence rate = (300/30,000) × 1000 = 10 

Therefore it is 10 per 1000 per year.

questions.text: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against an infectious disease. It was then incorporated by the health system. Which of the following is subsequently expected to happen?
questions.solution:
A new effective treatment for infectious disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby reducing prevalence.

Note: Both prevalence and incidence decrease but prevalence is the first to show a change in pattern. Hence, ‘prevalence decreases’ is the better answer.

questions.text: A new drug was approved for the treatment of prostate cancer. It has been shown to prevent early deaths but not cure the cancer. What is expected to happen to the cases of prostate cancer over a period of time?

choices.text: Increase in incidence, no change in prevalence
Decrease in incidence, increase in prevalence
Increase in incidence, decrease in prevalence
Increase in prevalence, no change in incidence

questions.solution:
A new drug that prevents death yet does not cure the disease will cause an increase in prevalence but the incidence remains the same.

In the given scenario, the drug reduces early deaths but does not cure prostate cancer. Hence, there is a paradoxical increase in the prevalence while the incidence remains the same.

Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as:

P = I X D

(I - Incidence and D - Mean duration)

This equation shows longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Note:

  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Cross product ratio can be arrived from:
questions.solution:
Cross product ratio (Odds ratio) can be obtained from the case-control study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: A person wants to study about the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, so he collects data about people diseased with lung cancer from government hospitals and the number of cigarette packets sold at the same time period. Which type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The type of study described is an ecological study as the unit of study is the population. The number of cigarette packets sold at the same time is data about the population.

Option A: The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is an individual.

Option C: There is no experiment done here. Hence, it is not experimental study.

Option D: Quasi-experiments are nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies done when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct a randomized controlled trial. The unit of study is therefore patients or individuals and not population.
